text.p: Italian debt markets ended nearly 50 basis points down on the day but recovered from the depth of the session's lows before dealers packed up for the weekend.
Traders said the BTP market had held up relatively well although some expected further correction when traders returned on Monday, given the sharp rally of the market in recent weeks.
"Everybody's waiting for a sell-off. A bit came this morning. But something is changing on BTPs in that we're waiting for a correction," one broker at a major UK bank in London said.
The March LIFFE future was 45 basis points down at 131.55 after touching 131.34 support.
The broker said he was expecting the BTP future to try trading lower at the start of next week, with a test down to 131.00 or a little below that level.
However it had been bought back well at 131.34 even though traders said volumes were pretty subdued for the day.
The July 2006 Btp ended 46 basis points down at 110.64 and was yielding 7.31 percent with a spread of 152 basis points over the 10-year benchmark Bund.
Another broker at a large U.S. bank in London said there was still plenty of foreign interest in Btps even though volume was not as substantial as that in early January.
Longer term, the broker said, investors expected the spread over Germany to close in further.
On the political front, the market was still waiting to see whether metal workers' unions and their employers would ever reach an accord over renewing contracts.
Prime Minister Romano Prodi met three main union confederation leaders earlier on Friday and the government has called union and industry chiefs to a meeting on Monday.
Traders say the market will watch whether Prodi can bring about a deal, regarding it as a test of his strength as a leader. --Charlotte Cooper, Milan bureau +39 2 6612507
